description: In this series, Justin is going to combine the powers of the Express web framework with the power of AngularJS on the front end to create a weather forecast web application. Express will be used to proxy the request from the front end to the DarkSky API that is being consumed as a measure of hiding the credentials that are necessary for making the request. Moreover, Angular will interact with the proxy in order to obtain the information needed to render the application. If you want to see how this application comes together, then join us!
descriptionMD: In this series, Justin is going to combine the powers of the Express web framework with the power of AngularJS on the front end to create a weather forecast web application. Express will be used to proxy the request from the front end to the DarkSky API that is being consumed as a measure of hiding the credentials that are necessary for making the request. Moreover, Angular will interact with the proxy in order to obtain the information needed to render the application. If you want to see how this application comes together, then join us!
name: Weather Application with Angular Express
subtitle: Angular and Express... Putting it together!

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin give a general overview of what to expect in the upcoming Weather App with AngularJS and Express series. They cover topics like who is the intended audience, what the scope of the series will cover, and what are some specific topics that will be addressed.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

[MUSIC]

I wanna learn a little
bit about Webpack and

39

I wanna learn how to use Express and

41
00:02:15.200 --> 00:02:19.520

42
00:02:19.520 --> 00:02:24.393
So this is definitely about powering up,

43

45
00:02:31.140 --> 00:02:37.288
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Justin and Zach discuss the purpose of the Weather App with Angular JS & Express, what is going to be built in the series, interacting with an API, creating the API, what technologies we will use, what the DarkSky API is, overview of the DarkSky documentation, how to create a DarkSky account, looking at data through a JSON Viewer plugin through Chrome, DarkSky protocol including non-pay vs. pay for service, protecting your API key, and additional setup needed.
episodes.title: Setup and Introduction
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

Hello and thank you for

00:06:08.470 --> 00:06:12.672
Now, what I'm not gonna show you, is they
will send you an email to confirm and

00:06:12.672 --> 00:06:16.175
this is to keep people from building
bots that will sign up for a lot

128
00:06:16.175 --> 00:06:18.843
of accounts and then just proxy through-
>> Right, right, right.

129
00:06:18.843 --> 00:06:20.330
>> - a great deal of accounts.

130
00:06:20.330 --> 00:06:24.470
So you do have to click on the email and
verify that.

131
00:06:24.470 --> 00:06:28.480
There is no commitment as
far as pay when you sign up.

00:06:28.480 --> 00:06:31.280
You don't have to enter a credit

Now, at the time on the recording that

00:17:53.116 --> 00:17:56.873

00:18:08.500 --> 00:18:13.150

00:18:25.680 --> 00:18:28.090

00:18:28.090 --> 00:18:32.940
you should set up a proxy server to

00:18:32.940 --> 00:18:36.580

00:18:36.580 --> 00:18:39.110

episodes.description: Justin and Zach cover what a Proxy is, CORS disabling on Darksky, hiding credentials during deployment, building a simple Express Server, testing the server, creating our own HTTP based API, and building the first weather route using a router.
episodes.title: Building the Proxy

.json.

episodes.description: Justin and Zach cover using Webpack for our Weather App, what a Webpack is, transforming newer JS code to a more compatible code, managing assets such as images, allowing for common syntax using module system, using Webpack to allow us to use module system with front end code, using NPM to manage our dependencies, front end and back end code in separate folders, webpack-cli, webpack-cli init, running with node, plugins for webpack, loaders for webpack, HtmlWebpackPlugin, wire up the webpack plugin, inject the JavaScript, and inject some CSS.
episodes.title: Up and Going with Webpack

Because even though we're using AngularJS,

Well, the dumb components are more or
less purely presentational and

all they do is run back to the staple, or

But ultimately, that's where our app

00:02:21.610 --> 00:02:22.560

there is a lot of video

You wanna make sure you watch every video,

And great job as usual Justin, awesome.

I'm very excited cuz we're gonna continue

Right now,

So if you copy and paste a lot and now you

So it's almost like,

And services can serve other,

And so we have that, and

This is the first time I've

And that's the reason being is, eh,

Now I say that in quotes because it's in

Also, being part of the file name,

So I like to check it just

And then the question is,

Well, it's inside the services folder and

Keep wanting to type server for

So there it is.

And then I do get some leeway

But my recommendation is if I'm

00:09:47.430 --> 00:09:50.240
all of your services should

All of your components should be

you should group them by what they are,

service component, service component,

And you'll see me do that and you don't

Now there are a couple of
ways of building a service.

00:10:10.290 --> 00:10:14.742
And I'm gonna call this weather

The actual thing is the class

But I'm gonna use the service keyword, or

Now in our intro to Angular JS

services, those are not [INAUDIBLE],

there's actually a couple of other

If you write an ES6, ES2015 class,

behind the scenes Angular calls the new

00:10:46.740 --> 00:10:49.950
So, necessary if I use factory and
gets weird.

186
00:10:49.950 --> 00:10:51.740
I could do some crazy stuff and

00:10:51.740 --> 00:10:55.620
make it work with that factory

00:10:55.620 --> 00:10:56.710
So this is all wired up.

And now if I'm come back

let's just list this is

And we're gonna leave there,

We're not doing any changes yet.

We just want to see if it gets

So console.log, weather.

00:11:19.720 --> 00:11:21.850
So I'm just calling it weather.

You can call it whatever you want.

00:11:22.930 --> 00:11:23.860
You can call it.

>> Bob.

>> Bob, yeah.

You can definitely call it Bob,

However, I know that if it's injected

And in the context of this app,

So let's go check out, I haven't

export and

So let's come over here

00:21:15.170 --> 00:21:20.260

00:21:39.830 --> 00:21:42.960
Everything else is presentational and

00:22:18.965 --> 00:22:21.400
I know it's not a 0,0 as I said before.

376
00:22:21.400 --> 00:22:24.870
That's western Africa,
off in the Atlantic.

377
00:22:24.870 --> 00:22:27.026
I don't think minutely
makes a lot of sense.

378
00:22:27.026 --> 00:22:32.031
However, if I go for
something around 30, and

379
00:22:32.031 --> 00:22:38.270
then -100,
that's about middle of the United States.

380
00:22:40.350 --> 00:22:45.252
And then, if we run, there's hourly,
and look at there, there's minutely.

381
00:22:45.252 --> 00:22:46.022
>> Ooh!
>> I got lucky.

382
00:22:46.022 --> 00:22:47.021
Whoo!

383
00:22:47.021 --> 00:22:47.943
>> Ooh!

384
00:22:47.943 --> 00:22:50.501
>> Ooh, he's excited, I'm excited.

385
00:22:50.501 --> 00:22:51.830
Hopefully, you are as well.

386
00:22:51.830 --> 00:22:57.610
Now, if we look at minutely, we have
a structure very similar to hourly.

387
00:22:57.610 --> 00:23:03.211
We have summary and an icon,
and then, I think it's funny.

388
00:23:03.211 --> 00:23:05.319
What's the summary,
possible light rain for one hour?

389
00:23:05.319 --> 00:23:06.420
What's the icon for rain?

390
00:23:07.430 --> 00:23:09.850
I wonder if we go and
read these individual pieces?

391
00:23:11.240 --> 00:23:14.762
I wonder what they're
going to let us know?

392
00:23:14.762 --> 00:23:16.330
They're going to let us
know about the rain.

393
00:23:16.330 --> 00:23:17.290
>> Yep.

394
00:23:17.290 --> 00:23:21.430
>> And you'll notice in minutely, this
data attribute that we can repeat over.

395
00:23:21.430 --> 00:23:22.760
We can kind of duplicate.

396
00:23:24.040 --> 00:23:27.670
We get time precip intensity error.

397
00:23:27.670 --> 00:23:32.680
That's interesting, so
this API sometimes does change over time.

398
00:23:32.680 --> 00:23:34.731
And I've used it before.

399
00:23:34.731 --> 00:23:36.940
This used to be a lot more simplified.

400
00:23:36.940 --> 00:23:40.020
I'm pretty sure you got precip intensity,
and precip probability, but

401
00:23:40.020 --> 00:23:42.890
in newer additions they're
adding information.

402
00:23:42.890 --> 00:23:44.330
What is the error, right?

403
00:23:44.330 --> 00:23:50.763
If I have a .003% of
chance of precipitation,

404
00:23:50.763 --> 00:23:54.811
and the error is 0.001%.

405
00:23:58.091 --> 00:24:00.881
Excuse me this is intensity,
I'm sorry, I'm sorry.

406
00:24:00.881 --> 00:24:05.641
So this is very light Give or take,
and it's still very light, but

407
00:24:05.641 --> 00:24:08.958
precip probability is 0.03, all right?

408
00:24:08.958 --> 00:24:12.252
Now, we have to look,
because it may be these are percentages,

409
00:24:12.252 --> 00:24:15.364
or these are just decimal
representations of percentages.

410
00:24:15.364 --> 00:24:18.022
We'll get to that when we finally nail

411
00:24:18.022 --> 00:24:21.357
down what our component
is going to render out.

412
00:24:21.357 --> 00:24:24.682
But this gives you, roughly, the next,

413
00:24:24.682 --> 00:24:29.442
if I'm not mistaken,
about 60 minutes, plus or minus.

414
00:24:29.442 --> 00:24:34.155
They may have changed it to add
additional times of precipitation,

415
00:24:34.155 --> 00:24:35.899
that's all you can get.

416
00:24:35.899 --> 00:24:39.676
Because that's what's likely to change
in a pretty quick minute, right?

417
00:24:39.676 --> 00:24:42.703
Again, just a throw back, you walk
outside, it wasn't gonna rain, hey,

418
00:24:42.703 --> 00:24:43.783
it's raining everywhere.

419
00:24:43.783 --> 00:24:47.047
So, that's all we get, we don't get
temperature, doesn't really make sense.

420
00:24:47.047 --> 00:24:50.875
We don't get any of that finer grain
detail, all we get is for precipitation,

421
00:24:50.875 --> 00:24:52.562
and that's perfectly okay by me.

422
00:24:52.562 --> 00:24:56.610
We're gonna render this out very
similarly that we did to hourly, but

423
00:24:56.610 --> 00:25:01.224
I don't think that makes sense in the
grand scheme of things over the long term.

424
00:25:01.224 --> 00:25:07.013
This kind of lends itself to
almost like a time series graph,

425
00:25:07.013 --> 00:25:10.426
but who knows, who knows, right?

426
00:25:10.426 --> 00:25:13.170
I'm teasing again a little bit Zach,
who knows?

427
00:25:13.170 --> 00:25:17.472
So let's just get that rendered out,
so we don't have that pretag there.

428
00:25:17.472 --> 00:25:18.777
I come to Minutely, and

429
00:25:18.777 --> 00:25:22.638
let's create that section that we've
seen in some of the other ones.

430
00:25:22.638 --> 00:25:27.687
And so ng-if, there is weatherData,

431
00:25:27.687 --> 00:25:32.894
only render it if there is weatherData.

432
00:25:32.894 --> 00:25:39.151
And well, let's create a summary,
and that's a paragraph,

433
00:25:39.151 --> 00:25:43.882
and ctrl.summary, weatherData.summary.

434
00:25:48.346 --> 00:25:52.399
And, let's actually create
a heading of Minutely.

435
00:25:55.890 --> 00:26:00.505
And ul, and ng-repeat, again, this is for

436
00:26:00.505 --> 00:26:05.008
each data point in the weatherData.data.

437
00:26:05.008 --> 00:26:08.119
Sadly, sometimes when
you use external APIs,

438
00:26:08.119 --> 00:26:12.099
naming gets a little interesting,
so weatherData.data.

439
00:26:12.099 --> 00:26:18.478
And then for each one of those points,
let's just say,

440
00:26:18.478 --> 00:26:24.452
point, you actually have
to write the expression,

441
00:26:24.452 --> 00:26:28.663
point in this weatherData.data for

442
00:26:28.663 --> 00:26:32.219
point.precipProbability.

443
00:26:34.781 --> 00:26:38.578
Let's just say Prob, and

444
00:26:38.578 --> 00:26:42.719
then dash, and the time, so

445
00:26:42.719 --> 00:26:47.897
point.time times 1000 type,

446
00:26:47.897 --> 00:26:51.533
date, short, as such.

447
00:26:51.533 --> 00:26:58.144
All right, so there we go, there we go,
we've got our nice little refresh,

448
00:26:58.144 --> 00:27:02.639
and we're going to go
back to 30 negative 100.

449
00:27:02.639 --> 00:27:05.678
And boom, we have hourly and
we have minutely.

450
00:27:05.678 --> 00:27:08.944
And notice if we look here,

451
00:27:08.944 --> 00:27:13.781
probability of rain starts fairly low.

452
00:27:13.781 --> 00:27:20.188
And over what appears to be the next hour,
we get a spike of about 50%,

453
00:27:20.188 --> 00:27:25.352
and then it tails off, and
then, yup, it goes back down.

454
00:27:25.352 --> 00:27:29.651
So when you read this in a line by line,
it's not as easy to read, so this

455
00:27:29.651 --> 00:27:34.106
is probably a better place to represent
the data in a different capacity.

456
00:27:34.106 --> 00:27:38.283
But now we have all of our components
put together, they're all kind of

457
00:27:38.283 --> 00:27:42.263
there ready to go and we can make
decisions component by component.

458
00:27:42.263 --> 00:27:46.465
>> Justin, I'm starting to see a pattern
here, is this why we leave all the data in

459
00:27:46.465 --> 00:27:50.134
the app component and then just pass
it along, is that why we do that?

460
00:27:50.134 --> 00:27:53.051
>> That is, and
you're alluding to this pattern, and

461
00:27:53.051 --> 00:27:55.185
I'm gonna zoom out just a little bit.

462
00:27:55.185 --> 00:27:58.336
Notice we have a search,
which is an interaction component,

463
00:27:58.336 --> 00:28:03.005
it tells the app component to search, but
then current-weather, hourly-weather, and

464
00:28:03.005 --> 00:28:06.535
minutely-weather, I wonder what
each one of those components do.

465
00:28:06.535 --> 00:28:10.541
Yeah, it's a little repetitive,
and we can probably abstract this,

466
00:28:10.541 --> 00:28:14.772
now I'm not necessarily gonna do that
here, we could do some crazy stuff.

467
00:28:14.772 --> 00:28:18.567
I like declarative, understandable more so
than trying to abstract and

468
00:28:18.567 --> 00:28:19.508
make it the best.

469
00:28:19.508 --> 00:28:23.306
So get it working first, so
current-weather, I wonder what it does.

470
00:28:23.306 --> 00:28:26.501
Well, it needs some weather data,
it needs the current-weather data,

471
00:28:26.501 --> 00:28:28.724
and then it probably renders
the current weather.

472
00:28:28.724 --> 00:28:32.560
If I wanted to change that,
I just go fix that part,

473
00:28:32.560 --> 00:28:36.115
hourly-weather, minutely-weather.

474
00:28:36.115 --> 00:28:40.128
Well, that makes sense,
they're just to those pieces.

475
00:28:40.128 --> 00:28:44.369
So this pattern kind of propagates
out of the fact that we

476
00:28:44.369 --> 00:28:47.527
have made the decision, or when I say we,

477
00:28:47.527 --> 00:28:53.416
I have made the decision that all of
the information is in the app controller.

478
00:28:53.416 --> 00:28:57.225
And all the information getting and
maintaining and stuff,

479
00:28:57.225 --> 00:29:00.369
all of the stable portion
is in the app component.

480
00:29:00.369 --> 00:29:06.301
All of the presentation aspects are then
delegated out to rid other components.

481
00:29:06.301 --> 00:29:09.497
And then the search component
does have some interactions, but

482
00:29:09.497 --> 00:29:12.869
some of our other ones might as well,
but they're still not going to

483
00:29:12.869 --> 00:29:15.910
keep internal state that we have
to keep track of ourselves.

484
00:29:15.910 --> 00:29:17.263
We're gonna leave that to the app,

485
00:29:17.263 --> 00:29:19.077
it makes it a little bit
easier to reason about.

486
00:29:19.077 --> 00:29:22.673
And especially when we look at this HTML,
if I were to hand you this and

487
00:29:22.673 --> 00:29:24.905
you didn't know a lot about programming,

488
00:29:24.905 --> 00:29:28.440
you could probably make a pretty
good guess about what's going on.

489
00:29:28.440 --> 00:29:32.091
>> Hourly and minutely-weather component,
this is what you've been watching,

490
00:29:32.091 --> 00:29:33.278
Justin, any last words?

491
00:29:33.278 --> 00:29:38.454
>> Well, we're just touching the very
tip of what we hope to get done.

492
00:29:38.454 --> 00:29:42.389
Because there's some parts about this that
I don't particularly like and then, well,

493
00:29:42.389 --> 00:29:45.438
there's some parts that I think we
could just make better outright.

494
00:29:45.438 --> 00:29:48.932
So definitely stay tuned,
you never know what we're gonna get into.

495
00:29:48.932 --> 00:29:52.792
>> Awesome, more great episodes of
Weather App with Angular JS and Express,

496
00:29:52.792 --> 00:29:53.722
coming your way.

497
00:29:53.722 --> 00:29:56.250
And there is an awful lot
of content already, so

498
00:29:56.250 --> 00:29:58.983
make sure you watch all of
the videos in the series.

499
00:29:58.983 --> 00:30:01.408
And thank you for
watching DevPro.TV, remember,

500
00:30:01.408 --> 00:30:03.844
a good Dev Pro is always learning,
I'm Zack Memos.

501
00:30:03.844 --> 00:30:04.659
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

502
00:30:04.659 --> 00:30:06.856
>> And we will see you very soon.

503
00:30:06.856 --> 00:30:12.150
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Justin and Zach continue building the Weather App, discuss Unfriendly Search, look at Google for APIS, searching for city/state instead of latitude & longitude, adding to the Proxy, adding to the Weather Service, and building a new route.
episodes.title: Adding Google Location Search
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.763 --> 00:00:14.719
Hello and thank you for
choosing DEVPRO.TV,

3
00:00:14.719 --> 00:00:16.230
helping you learn wherever you go.

4
00:00:16.230 --> 00:00:18.300
I'm your host Zach Memos.

5
00:00:18.300 --> 00:00:22.488
As we continue with the series
Weather App with Angular JS and Express.

6
00:00:22.488 --> 00:00:26.440
And we're gonna be adding Google
location search in this episode.

7
00:00:26.440 --> 00:00:29.610
The person bringing us all
the information we need is IT expert, and

8
00:00:29.610 --> 00:00:32.485
all around good guy,
Justin Dennison, right over here.

9
00:00:32.485 --> 00:00:33.315
How you doing?
So good to see you.

10
00:00:33.315 --> 00:00:36.667
>> Well, I'll go with the expert, but I
don't know if I'm necessarily a good guy.

11
00:00:36.667 --> 00:00:38.474
>> You are.
>> But in order to show good faith in

12
00:00:38.474 --> 00:00:40.765
that assertion,
is how are you today, Zach?

13
00:00:40.765 --> 00:00:41.808
>> Well, I'm doing great, and

14
00:00:41.808 --> 00:00:44.328
I'm excited that we're continuing
on with building the Weather App.

15
00:00:44.328 --> 00:00:47.705
And it looks like we've got
the application working and so forth.

16
00:00:47.705 --> 00:00:50.265
But we can do more with that, right?

17
00:00:50.265 --> 00:00:50.765
I mean, can't we?

18
00:00:52.005 --> 00:00:56.606
>> Yeah, and typically when people see
this first iteration, they're like, hey,

19
00:00:56.606 --> 00:01:00.024
so this latitude,
longitude search is not really friendly,

20
00:01:00.024 --> 00:01:02.804
because I don't know my latitude and
longitude.

21
00:01:02.804 --> 00:01:06.689
I have to go actively seek out my latitude
and longitude in order to search for

22
00:01:06.689 --> 00:01:07.430
the weather.

23
00:01:07.430 --> 00:01:10.610
Well, if we were actually putting
this up there as a product,

24
00:01:10.610 --> 00:01:15.250
it's probably not gonna go over too,
well because of that exact reason.

25
00:01:15.250 --> 00:01:19.700
So, it would almost be nice if I mean
you could search for city-state or

26
00:01:19.700 --> 00:01:24.190
maybe zip code or something of that nature
and hopefully that's what we're gonna do.

27
00:01:24.190 --> 00:01:27.320
>> Well so, how do we go about
with the ability to search for

28
00:01:27.320 --> 00:01:28.290
a location and so forth.

29
00:01:28.290 --> 00:01:29.010
I mean how do we do it?

30
00:01:29.010 --> 00:01:32.700
>> So, there's several ways and
the approach that we're gonna take in this

31
00:01:32.700 --> 00:01:36.850
episode is,
actually using the Google Geo code API.

32
00:01:36.850 --> 00:01:40.748
Now, geocoding is,
I always get these reversed.

33
00:01:40.748 --> 00:01:44.120
We're actually gonna take a location and
look up the latitude and

34
00:01:44.120 --> 00:01:47.210
longitude in order to
then look up the weather.

35
00:01:47.210 --> 00:01:50.270
There's an addition one where I can
give the latitude and longitude and

36
00:01:50.270 --> 00:01:53.790
it will give me back well
the location pretty close.

37
00:01:53.790 --> 00:01:58.410
Now, what it ends up being is
a location has a fairly precise, right,

38
00:01:58.410 --> 00:02:02.270
a fairly up to the hundredths, or

39
00:02:02.270 --> 00:02:05.940
maybe even thousandths or ten thousandths
of a degree of latitude and longitude.

40
00:02:05.940 --> 00:02:11.530
But if I say I want 30 degrees north and
negative 120, and

41
00:02:11.530 --> 00:02:17.130
that would be west, then it's gonna say,
yeah here some close places.

42
00:02:17.130 --> 00:02:21.010
So this is geocode and reverse geocode,
I always mix those up.

43
00:02:21.010 --> 00:02:25.020
I'm pretty sure geocode is like, I give
it a location and it gives me the lat, no

44
00:02:25.020 --> 00:02:28.571
excuse me, geocode, I give it a latitude
and longitude, it gives me a location.

45
00:02:28.571 --> 00:02:30.961
>> Right.
>> Reverse geocode, I give it a Location,

46
00:02:30.961 --> 00:02:33.081
and it gives me a latitude and longitude.

47
00:02:33.081 --> 00:02:37.141
And hopefully, and that's what we're
gonna do, and in order to do that,

48
00:02:37.141 --> 00:02:41.467
there's a few steps that we have to take
in order to get this kind of to coalesce.

49
00:02:41.467 --> 00:02:46.270
And well, we have to change our proxy,
that's probably gonna be the easiest way,

50
00:02:46.270 --> 00:02:50.180
because this API is a RESTful endpoint,
well, It's an endpoint,

51
00:02:50.180 --> 00:02:51.640
it's an HTTP endpoint.

52
00:02:51.640 --> 00:02:58.170
I make no strong assertions about
how strong it conforms to RESTful.

53
00:02:58.170 --> 00:03:02.620
I realize I said strong like four times in
that sentence, but that is for emphasis.

54
00:03:02.620 --> 00:03:03.630
>> That's right.

55
00:03:03.630 --> 00:03:07.410
>> So, we're gonna use Google to look at
the location, and then when we get that

56
00:03:07.410 --> 00:03:11.700
information back, we're then gonna to
call to Dark Sky to give us the weather.

57
00:03:11.700 --> 00:03:16.220
And a lot of people ask me, well,
why doesn't Dark Sky just offer that?

58
00:03:16.220 --> 00:03:21.330
And to some extent, it's probably because
Google already has the infrastructure.

59
00:03:21.330 --> 00:03:25.990
They have Google Maps, it's in Google's
best interest to be able to support

60
00:03:25.990 --> 00:03:30.390
this type of operation, especially when
it comes to searching for restaurants,

61
00:03:30.390 --> 00:03:32.780
searching for places,
searching for car dealerships.

62
00:03:32.780 --> 00:03:37.110
Right, all of the things that Google does,
it's kind of just ancillary to their basic

63
00:03:37.110 --> 00:03:41.680
operations and they've exposed this
as a service to, well, you, me,

64
00:03:41.680 --> 00:03:44.520
and whoever can figure out how
to actually make use of it.

65
00:03:44.520 --> 00:03:45.140
>> That's right, and

66
00:03:45.140 --> 00:03:48.170
the Google can even see the freckles
on your arm from outer space.

67
00:03:48.170 --> 00:03:48.700
That's right.

68
00:03:48.700 --> 00:03:49.810
>> That they can, that they can.

69
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:51.530
So-
>> [LAUGH]

70
00:03:51.530 --> 00:03:52.093
>> That they can.

71
00:03:52.093 --> 00:03:54.450
We're gonna go with it,
we're gonna go with it.

72
00:03:54.450 --> 00:03:59.130
Freckles from outer space, please
don't let that be the only thing that

73
00:03:59.130 --> 00:04:00.920
you kind of sink in from this episode.

74
00:04:00.920 --> 00:04:02.090
So-
>> No, don't do that.

75
00:04:02.090 --> 00:04:03.550
>> Well, are you ready?

76
00:04:03.550 --> 00:04:04.514
>> Yeah, what's first?

77
00:04:04.514 --> 00:04:05.750
What are we going to do first?

78
00:04:05.750 --> 00:04:09.750
>> Well, let's go ahead and
take a look at our proxy, and

79
00:04:09.750 --> 00:04:14.790
from there that'll allow us to make
an appropriate plan, all right?

80
00:04:14.790 --> 00:04:18.980
So, if we take a look at my screen here,
I have Atom open, and

81
00:04:18.980 --> 00:04:24.000
everything's still running
in these two windows,

82
00:04:24.000 --> 00:04:28.430
right, and I have my webpack compiling,
and I have my proxy service running.

83
00:04:28.430 --> 00:04:32.110
And this proxy service is
running using NodeIndex.js.

84
00:04:32.110 --> 00:04:37.060
So that's something that we need to be
aware of when we're making these changes.

85
00:04:37.060 --> 00:04:42.045
So we may have to adjust that, and
if we look at proxy, well, let's just make

86
00:04:42.045 --> 00:04:46.380
sure that all our packages.json is here,
all right, cool deal.

87
00:04:46.380 --> 00:04:51.320
So that's still there and if we look at
index.js we have this weather router and

88
00:04:51.320 --> 00:04:55.060
we wire it up and
ultimately that is our proxy service.

89
00:04:55.060 --> 00:04:58.430
This weather router has
a single route in it.

90
00:04:58.430 --> 00:05:03.350
And it's to /weather/:lat,:lon,
that's what we had initially.

91
00:05:03.350 --> 00:05:06.190
And this uses credentials that
were kind of hiding away, right?

92
00:05:07.620 --> 00:05:13.780
Now, what we want is the ability
to look up a weather by location.

93
00:05:13.780 --> 00:05:17.350
And what I mean by location is
like you give me a zip code or

94

Because we can get latitude and longitude

So if I come up and

episodes.description: Justin and Zach cover deploying the web app without Heroku, using 'GITHUB Pages,' hosting our site through 'GIT REPO,' setting up 'GH-PAGES' as a node script, installing the package, setting up a 'GITHUB REPO,' installing the 'GH-PAGES' package, adding the Deploy script, and deployment.

00:24:20.170 --> 00:24:21.650
>> For us, right?

414
00:24:21.650 --> 00:24:23.170
We do need a little bit of styling,

415
00:24:23.170 --> 00:24:27.570
I don't say that I wanna have
the greatest styling ever.

416
00:24:27.570 --> 00:24:29.080
We also need to take the data and

417
00:24:29.080 --> 00:24:33.500
represent it in a little bit different way
than just list the items on the screen.

418
00:24:34.510 --> 00:24:36.810
So there's a few other things
that I want to get done.

419
00:24:36.810 --> 00:24:38.990
A little bit of style, maybe add a chart.

420
00:24:38.990 --> 00:24:42.160
Because minutely,
that's probably the easiest way to see it.

421
00:24:42.160 --> 00:24:46.220
If it just goes up or down, it's gonna let
you know about the precipitation rate.

422
00:24:46.220 --> 00:24:47.760
And then hourly.

423
00:24:47.760 --> 00:24:50.370
And we need images, right?

424
00:24:50.370 --> 00:24:53.200
Because each one of these
has an icon name, and

425
00:24:53.200 --> 00:24:58.490
we can see how to use images as
static assets, deploy those,

426
00:24:58.490 --> 00:25:02.420
and now we actually start seeing
images in nice, pretty colors.

427
00:25:02.420 --> 00:25:06.130
Again, I do not say I'm
a wonderful designer.

428
00:25:06.130 --> 00:25:08.560
So whatever we get will well,

429
00:25:08.560 --> 00:25:12.550
hopefully you're happy with it because it
makes me feel good just to give it a try.

430
00:25:12.550 --> 00:25:13.463
So that's that's were going.

431
00:25:13.463 --> 00:25:15.428
Preferably do have a few
more things to do.

432
00:25:15.428 --> 00:25:19.230
>> Function over form, so don't expect
fluffy clouds of raining bunnies and

433
00:25:19.230 --> 00:25:19.870
things like that.

434
00:25:19.870 --> 00:25:22.290
So weather app with AngularJS and express.

435
00:25:22.290 --> 00:25:23.620
Lots of videos in this series.

436
00:25:23.620 --> 00:25:26.060
Make sure you watch them all,
you'll be very glad you did.

437
00:25:26.060 --> 00:25:29.460
And a good dev pro is always learning,
did you know that?

438
00:25:29.460 --> 00:25:30.550
I'm Zach Memos.

439
00:25:30.550 --> 00:25:31.510
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

440
00:25:31.510 --> 00:25:32.586
>> And thank you for
watching, we'll see you soon.

441
00:25:32.586 --> 00:25:37.573
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin they will make the Weather App more visually appealing by using the CSS framework Tachyons. Here they take you from installation of Tachyons, including it in the build, and using the examples from the Tachyons documentation as a template to improve the Weather App.
episodes.title: Adding Some Style

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin tackle the Hourly data in our Weather App. Here they use Tachyons to make the data more visually appealing as well as giving it a side-scrolling effect.
episodes.title: Scrollable Houly Component

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin finish up the Weather App by making the minutely data more readable through charting. They use NVD3 to chart the data, explaining each step. They also discuss why you would want to chart with this method instead of using HTML5.
episodes.title: Minutely Component Chart
